page.text: Paul Kuhn – Town of Cary Parks, Recreation, and Cultural Resources
Denise Dickens – Town of Cary Parks, Recreation, and Cultural Resources
Doug McRainey – Town of Cary Parks, Recreation, and Cultural Resources
Graham Smith – DHM Design (Senior Associate/Landscape Architect)
Kay Struffolino – PRCR Advisory Board (lived in Cary since 1972)
Robert Bush – Greenway Committee (lives in Carpenter Village)
Paul – Welcome, Thanks, and Introduced Design Team
Graham – Gave Overview of the following items shown in the powerpoint presentation
Site Analysis(Inventory)-Surrounding Land Use; Hydrology and Slope; Plant Communities; Edges
Site Analysi s – Synthesized All Analysis Maps
What does agricultural sense of the site mean?
What are design ideas that the team has thought of?
Who is in control of final decisions, how much say does the community have?
What are the issues with vehicle access to the site?
Carpenter Town Lane – not a preferred vehicle access point.
Concerns about safety after dark and light pollution.
What time are the parks supposed to be closed?
How long are the lights turned on during the night?
TOWN: Check out how the edges of Walnut Street Park were developed. Not clear cut.
Walnut Street & Sears Farm Park a good example of a small parking lot.
Lots of issues with parking lots and playgrounds adjacent to neighbors -related to vandalism,
Has anyone thought about relocating a farm building to the site? Concern for historic
preservation. Could be a cost effective choice. Possible Tobacco barn near Carp Elem
Excited about the site being developed into a park.
Community has a lot of “tweens” (9-12 yr olds) which need their own place to gather/play.
Consider a variety of ages using the site.
It’s hard to be excited about the park until the access point is decided.
Hamilton Hedge & Carpenter Lane are used as cut throughs at high speeds.
Does the site have to go through SHPO since it’s adjacent to historic property?
TOWN: Funding has been approved for Master plan phase only at this point.
Carpenter Town Lane character is worth preserving.
Not everyone has kids. Dog walkers seem to be the most active people on the site.
Will the sculpture be a strange object that doesn’t fit in?
Is a public restroom necessary? Concerned about location and maintenance?
We do not want a basketball court.
How will the park effect our property values?
This park will have a legacy beyond our time in the neighborhood.
Maybe we should aim at a demographic for an older population, due to other areas close by for
Quiet area to sit and be outdoors.
Lots of pedestrian connections into the neighborhood would be fantastic.
Could a senior center or farmers market scale building fit on this amount of land?
Please maintain a vegetated edge to the site between the houses and the park.
Consider ways to mitigate sound from Louis Stephens and Morrisville Carpenter road.
It would be interesting to see more abstract art in Cary.
The farmers market scene has grown in Cary and could be considered in the design.
Where is the closest basketball court?
American Eagle flight crashed nearby to the site 17 years ago. Perhaps a memorial could be
integrated into the park? Private funding is available.
There are 6 basketball courts within 1 mile to the site.
Areas with steep slopes could be used to create quieter places.
Views into the park could provide more security by police, and the long view across to Howard
Farm site is a special connection.
Modify streetyard buffers to allow for larger farm areas to tie together- particularly the AM Howard
Can the parking lot be put on the Howard Farm site creating a more central parking area?
Could you add a ped. Bridge?
How would you discourage people from cutting between houses to enter the park?
Where would the connections into the park?
600 WADE AVENUE, RALEIGH NORTH CAROLINA 27605 | T: 919.805.3586 | F: 919.832.7901
Town of Cary – Engineering Conference Room
Paul Kuhn – Town of Cary Parks, Recreation, and Cultural Resources Department
Graham Smith – DHM Design (Senior Associate/Landscape Architect)
Sean Dolle – Falcon Engineering (Dept Manager/Civil Engineer)
Kyle Hubert– Town of Cary Engineering Department (Project Manager)
1) Graham and Paul gave Proposed Park Overview
2) Graham discussed the Access to Park’ Issue – as the main reason for the team being at DRC
a. Preferred Full Movement Access Location on Louis Stephens – conceptually approval by NCDOT
b. Discussed Draft approval letter provided by NCDOT
Showed possible lane/median modifications on drawing
3) Jerry Jensen (Traffic Engineering)– discussed that we will most likely need to do some sort of traffic analysis
for the intersections (two existing and one proposed) along Louis Stephens to adequately validate the
possible full movement access point. He noted that the Town will try to help gather baseline information
and/or proposed traffic counts, but he was not sure if the Town had any relevant data for this section of
Louis Stephens and that we may have to hire outside consultant to tabulate data.
4) Jerry Jensen (Traffic Engineering)– noted that the design team would have to ask for a waiver to the Town’s
connectivity ordinance (Section 7-10 of the Land Development Ordinance) if we were not going to connect
to Carpenter Town Lane. That is a required secondary access point for the park per the Town’s LDO. He
stated that he did not think that his department would support this waiver, but that Town Council would
5) Shuyan Tian (Utilities)– discussion of two possible utility issues that may affect site development:
a. Need for the ‘developer’ (Town in this instance) to run a 12” waterline along the entire frontage of
site on Louis Stephens Road due to their ordinance requirements.
b. Need for the ‘developer’ (Town in this instance) to run a 20” re-use waterline along the entire
frontage of the site on Morrisville Carpenter Road due to their ordinance requirements.

text.i: CLARIFICATION: Later clarified by Paul Kuhn, Shuyan, and Falcon Engineering that this line would not be
mandated for this site development, but would be required for any development occurring on A.M.
Howard site to the north – related to the fact that the A.M. Howard site is within the ‘service area’ for the
re-use line, but Carpenter Park site is not.

and evaluation of Louis Stephens and Morrisville Carpenter.

b. 12” Water Line – need to be extended along entire frontage of Louis Stephens
i. Review Magnolia plans – should be a payment in lieu fee somewhere that can be applied

text.i: I don't remember fee payment for this section of the waterline. Mostly likely the Town
decided not to require this waterline at the time to avoid the waterline crossing the
street to be installed on the developer's side of the road.
Utility payment-in-lieu are dumped into the general fund and are not saved for specific
projects. Therefore, you will not have any additional fund for the waterline even if the

page.text: i. Moving in whole or tear down and rebuild?

iv. ACTION: Discuss moving building options with Landon/Sean (with their Builders of Hope
background) and with design team. Graham to get back to Doug and Paul the options –
4) Creation of Possible Pond – Should it be considered?

text.i: I’ll lead off by saying that the USACE’s permits are being revised starting next week (they do this every 5 years so nothing
particularly special). I’m not aware of any drastic changes but you never know. Assuming everything stays the same, they way
that the USACE has handled this type of issue in the past is if the pond was drained less than 2 years ago we can say it was for
maintenance and then impound it again using a permit that doesn’t technically require preapproval. If the pond was drained
more than 2 years ago and we want to flood it a again we would have to go through the permitting process to account for any
impacts to wetlands. The USACE considers permanently flooding a wetland a “change in use” and therefore an impact.
Currently on a per project basis, impacts to wetlands less than ½ acre can utilize nationwide permits (NWPs) but that depends
on the specific activity. NWPs have a 45-day response time from the USACE. Wetland impacts between 1/10 and ½ acre also
require written approval from the NC Division of Water Quality (DWQ) using their general certifications that correspond with
the specific NWPs. Our wetlands in the location of the old pond is 33,866 sf – which is over ½ acre. Anything over ½ acre of
wetlands disturbed would require an individual permit from the USACE and a corresponding individual certification from the
DWQ. Straight forward IPs that are easily defendable and not excessive in their proposed impacts can take between 6 and 9
months (my best was 6). This one is pretty straight forward. The other aspect to consider is that the preparation for submitting
an IP is much more intense because you now have multiple state and federal agencies reviewing it and you have to address all
of their concerns. But an average IP being required by some type of commercial or residential development can average
Mitigation: The USACE can require mitigation for any impact but usually do so for any wetland impact over 1/10
acre. The mitigation is typically a 2:1 ratio but can be as high as 3:1 and as low as 1:1. This means if you impact 1/10
of an acre you are responsible for restoring 1/5 of an acre. There’s a much longer explanation to this too but that’s
Stormwater: The USACE will not allow a jurisdictional wetland or surface water (pond) be used to meet storm water
requirements. That being said, if there are no storm water requirements from the town or state then you can direct
storm water to the jurisdictional features. For this reason there may be some advantages to shifting the pond over
slightly and utilizing some of the non-wetland areas in the pond’s footprint for storm water.
In short, flooding the pond again is doable it’s just a matter of time and money. There may also be some alternatives to flooding the
pond that creates the same effect.

page.text: All agreed that the pond should be put back into the park – as long as permitting process
is not an obstruction to completion of project on time. Paul to reach out to Jamie Shern
at USACOE to assess our options.
Paul reached out to Jamie. Jamie was very positive in his response and noted his
willingness to help our project with this desire. Jamie then called Sean C. to continue the
dialogue. Sounds like we are going to move ahead with this concept.
5) Final Make Up of Design Committee is set
Graham to make agenda for Design Committee meeting.
6) Inclusion of Airline Memorial within Design Committee
b. Flexibility to integrate more closely into final park design? Yes.
Rich and Marie are part of Design Committee.
b. Basketball Court - leave in design concepts – maybe switch to ‘court sports’ area
e. Visibility from Roads vs Seclusion from Roads?

v. 12:00-1:00-Lunch In – with Staff (additional feedback and organize afternoon work)
vi. 1:00-3:30 – Continual Refinement and Feedback of Preferred Alternatives (Staff and Design
a. Keep as it is – however know that it may slide and push a bit. All agreed that the goal is to make
the park the best it can be and a ‘home run’, so do not compromise its quality with a forced
schedule. Schedule to be reevaluated week to week as items are researched and resolved.

page.text: 1) Explanation and Review of Three Park Concepts
a. Concept A – Access off of Louis Stephens + large earthen dam + memorial across dam
b. Concept B – Access off of Louis Stephens + sheetpile dam + terraces + memorial near proposed
Concept C – Access off of Carpenter Town Lane + tightly organized activity zone near parking +
Town staff offered input on the three concepts after their internal meeting on 18

text.i: general staff liked concept A. We like the size and shape of the pond and the earthen berm in its existing location. We like
the location of the play area and the basketball court, the trail entrance off Carpenter Towne is a nice feature. We also like
the seating/memorial area across the pond. The large buffer of trees and meadow to the adjacent residents is great. We
also would like to see integrated into the final concept the terraces shown in Concept B along with a larger open lawn area
that relates to the play area. We also like the structure that overlooks the pond in A and B.”

Andersons discussed concept of shade and quiet reflection as being important to them.
d. Discussion was had regarding hardscape material choices.
i. Wood was discussed as a good possible material to create shade (trellis/arbor/structure),
yet it was also agreed by all that it may not be an appropriate timeless material for lasting
ii. Stone was discussed as a likely possible material – in critical areas. Granite, sandstone,
limestone – all stone that may make for great material choice. Yet all agreed to use
judiciously as budgets are not unlimited.
iii. Concrete was discussed as well – good choice for paving in particular. Good for timeless
and inexpensive. Noted to not ‘make it too cold’ or ‘not welcoming’.
iv. Crushed granite, crushed stone, alternative pavers should also be considered.
e. Trees and/or shrubs – simply done and used to highlight the memorial or its overall design will be

The following are generalized notes on all comments/questions heard at the meeting:
Terraces up to the water and the "split" buildings in concept "B" everyone liked
Relationship of the parking lot, basketball court and play area on "A" was strong
Large open mowed grass field on opposite side of the pond shown in concept "c" was also preferred
Paved loop trails were positively received
Natural trails thru hardwoods were well received (Paul thinks we need to simplify these trails into possibly
Design team walked them thru the traffic issues and everyone seemed acceptable to the constraints we
Art Concept #1 (Gourds) - unanimous thumbs down - (but after the meeting... had a couple of side
comments from folks about discovering gourds in places around the park.)
Art Concept #3 (Corrugated Metal Columns) - majority like the reference to the buildings and the
Art Concept #2 (Totems).... Has possibility, but want to learn more about the objects in them
The following are individual comments/questions from the Citizens Design Committee:
Concept B – attractive edges to the pond. Seem clean and accessible and more usable than other
concepts. What does usable mean? Costs?
Concept B – Trails take most advantage of the woodland area in this plan. Pines are less disturbed by large
B – Story comes across most in how this plan was explained. Maybe add the large turf area from concept C
B – Like separation of restrooms from picnic shelter. In general, good idea to try to separate those
B – Seems like it had the most art locations.
A – seems like it has the least impact on the land and wetlands.
A – Paths seem appealing and have a nice flow including the parking.
A – Like the way the pond edges are treated because the pond might best be used as a reflective non
A – Memorial place with trees is good. More reflective and quiet than tunnel area.
C – Courts seem too close to structures if you had a private event.
Like the architectural concepts presented. Rocking chairs!
B – Terraces and natural systems are great.
Not a fan of two ponds. Lose the smaller pond.
Could the pond be used for fishing? If so, provide places for people to fish from i.e. from the structure.
A – Memorial seems more clear in this location.
B – View from bridge provides a subtle nod to the memorial crash site.
Pond is a unique opportunity worth using/playing/accessing. Kids sailing boats, chasing frogs etc. Are
there any restrictions to how the pond would be used?
Fishing might be inappropriate at this site due to conflicts with other park users. Dangerous, and lots of
Art Feedback – In general people like the totem and obelisk concepts.
B – How big are the ponds in this concept?
A – Seems like it is more respectful to preserving the most land as is.
Building structure on the lake is most appealing.
B - Is it possible to maintain the seccesional zones along the walk?
When will you do a cost estimate of the plans? Answer: Only estimate final concept.
What does the purple area signify?
Play area equipment? Maybe use simpler play equipment like see saw’s swings etc.
A – Looks more natural compared to B. B removes a lot of trees.
B – Increase of water doesn’t seem to deliver very much compared to what it removes.
A – Memorial feels the best here.
Architecture – Do they need to sit on concrete pads? Where might they be located?
Picnic Tables – Red material might be a nice type for tables.
Can anything be done with guard rail? At least improve appearance?
Take terraces from B and move it to A and bring large turf area from C to A.
How does the pond deal with Heavy rains like hurricanes etc? Would there be flooding?
B – Like the look but concerned with loss of trees.
Lake Crabtree is really close and offers activities for lakes like fishing etc.
A – Parking lot preferable. B parking lot seems like a waste of space.
Designated Drop off is a great feature.
B – Not responding to two lakes. But like the two buildings.
Could the main trail be a crushed granite rather than hard surfacing?
What materials would the main trail be? Accessibility issues.
Maybe have a lawn area sized half way between A and C.
C – Like spreading lawn to other size of lake to disperse people throughout the park.
Courts – Could it be half courts and or include volleyball/hockey etc?
C – Worst location for courts. Too close to everything else.
A – Play area is best in this scheme.
A – Walking paths and location of adjacent uses is the best/easiest for people to use.
Courts – Include more types of sports.
Is Right in right out a serious problem for these designs? Probably not, just unique to this park in Cary.
Maybe do a one way in on Carp Town Lane and one way out on LS Rd.
Probably will create more traffic regardless of park entrance location.
Possibly a system of speed bumps are going to be installed on Hamilton Hedge Rd. TBD.
What kind of traffic calming could we do to encourage people to use LS entrance?
When will we know for sure about LS Rd access? Answer: By June 27 Public Meeting.
What will we show at June public meeting? Reference 3 concepts, but show one final recommendation.
Will these concepts be on the website? Answer: Yes, and we will let you know when.
Memorial Location could feasibly be in a few locations. Tunnel could work too.
Memorial as educational tool. New residents wouldn’t know about the event otherwise.
Morrisville Carpenter crossing: Does it need to be widened? Could we do an Overpass?
Will ultimate size of water dictate how it’s used?
Lighting. How is it be addressed?
600 WADE AVENUE, RALEIGH NORTH CAROLINA 27605 | T: 919.805.3586 | F: 919.832.7901
Town of Cary – Engineering Conference Room
Paul Kuhn – Town of Cary Parks, Recreation, and Cultural Resources Department
Graham Smith – DHM Design (Senior Associate/Landscape Architect)
Kyle Hubert– Town of Cary Engineering Department (Project Manager)
1) Graham and Paul gave Proposed Park Overview
a. Graham discussed the Access to Park’ Issue
b. Preferred Full Movement Access Location on Louis Stephens – conceptually approval by NCDOT
Discussed Draft approval letter provided by NCDOT
d. Showed possible lane/median modifications on drawing
2) Jerry Jensen (Traffic Engineering) – appreciated the efforts that the park team has gone through to study
3) Jerry Jensen (Traffic Engineering)–noted that their staff still views the Louis Stephens full movement access
point as temporary and long term it may only be a right-in and right-out only as a permanent solution.
Noted that the Carpenter Town Lane access point is still required per the Town’s LDO’s Connectivity
ordinance (Section 7-10). He recommended that we keep in both access points. He stated that his
department would support a waiver from the LDO, but that Town Council would have to make final
4) Matt Flynn (Stormwater) – discussed the probability that stormwater quantity control to occur exclusively
in the pond and if that is all the pond ‘did’ then we can have an aerating fountain in it.
5) Matt Flynn (Stormwater) – discussed the concern about overflow weir for the pond and during the site plan
approval the team will need to review a lot of thise issues with his staff.
6) Matt Flynn (Stormwater) – noted that if we are under24% impervious on the site, then we will not have to
comply with Total Suspended Solids calculations (storm water runoff quality).
7) Kevin Hales (Planning) – noted that we should plan for a 30’ streetyard/streetscape buffer along the road
8) Kevin Hales (Planning) – noted that the terraces ‘look a little like an amphitheater’ and that if it were an
amphitheather it would change many items in terms of regulatory approval (parking, access, etc).
9) Kevin Hales (Planning) – noted concern about the site access from public right of way – particularly the
steps in the NW corner above the proposed underpass. Graham noted how all other access points were
ADA accessible (6 other locations) and that this one is until the steps., but that he would look into it
10) Kevin Hales (Planning) – noted that ‘hard edges’ are not allowed in upcoming text change to LDO for a
stormwater treatment device . Graham countered that this may not be a stormwater treatment device if it
was used for ‘quantity’ storage only. Kevin noted that there is a fine line there and might be best if plan

text.i: 5:30 pm – 6:05pm: Discussion with various individuals at Two Sets of Project Boards at Meeting

Graham – gave overview of the following items shown in the powerpoint presentation
Why is access from Carpenter Town Lane needed?
Why is there no sidewalk access from Northern neighborhoods down to Park site?
How deep is the pond and what are the opportunities for use? 4-6’ range.
What type of lighting will be in the park? Concern from Carpenter Town lane.
Is there talks about speed calming measures on side streets?
How will basketball courts be lighted – is there hours for the courts?
Will the basketball court create noise across the street?
We are proposing 2 ½ courts as opposed to 1 full court.
Could we include a volleyball court or tennis court?
Is there going to be a speed bump on Hamilton Hedge?
Nice process and creative plan. Access point from Carpenter Town Lane is dissapointing.
Could other structures be scattered around the park?
What is the security plan for the park? Dawn to Dusk hours… Will the park be locked?
Is this park similar to Preston Village park?
Speed bump clarification on Hamilton Hedge.
Tell us about the community garden? Funding, use, etc? Volunteer Program?
Carpenter Town Lane access should be located at Dominion Hill intersection, and deal with stream
Will there be parking on side streets?
The Carpenter Park Development is being proposed for construction in Cary,
North Carolina. The development is slated for construction in 2014 and will
include a 16 acre park with 30 parking spaces for park patrons.
shows the general site location of the park development. The proposed
development is located in the southeast quadrant of the SR 3014 (Morrisville-
Carpenter Road) / SR 3122 (Louis Stephens Drive) intersection with one site
driveway proposed to connect to SR 3122 (Louis Stephens Drive). This report
analyzes the effects of a full movement and / or partial restricted site driveway on
the existing roadway network for the 2012 existing year traffic conditions, the no-
build condition for 2030 (Condition 2), the full build-out condition for the year
2030 (Condition 3) and the full build-out condition for the year 2030 with any
The proposed site is currently undeveloped.
proposed project site location and position of the proposed site driveway
This report analyzes and presents the traffic impacts that the Carpenter Park
Development will have on the following (existing* and future) intersections:
 Carpenter Town Lane / SR 3122 (Louis Stephens Drive)
The impacts of the proposed site at these intersections will be evaluated during
the AM and PM peak hours of an average weekday. The following analysis is
based on the 2012 existing year traffic, the 2030 traffic with the addition of
ambient growth and without the proposed development, and the 2030 total traffic
with the addition of the estimated site-generated traffic produced by the
Carpenter Park Development. The report also analyzes the potential effects of
queuing at the intersections of SR 3014 (Morrisville-Carpenter Road) / SR 3122
(Louis Stephens Drive) and Site Driveway #1 / SR 3122 (Louis Stephens Drive).
Currently there are two approved background developments to be completed
within the surrounding region prior to the construction of the Carpenter Park
To account for area-wide 2013 ambient traffic growth, an annual growth rate
percentage of 3.0 percent per year was applied to the existing volumes. This
growth rate was calculated using area 2005 – 2009 AADT values provided by the
The project study area is currently serviced by two major corridors: SR 3014
(Morrisville-Carpenter Road) and SR 3122 (Louis Stephens Drive). In addition,
one minor facility and one site driveway complete the study area. The minor
facility includes Carpenter Town Lane. For future build-out there will be one full-
movement site driveway connecting to SR 3122 (Louis Stephens Drive).
In the project study area, there is one signalized and one unsignalized
intersection. The intersection of SR 3014 (Morrisville-Carpenter Road) / SR 3122
(Louis Stephens Drive) is signalized where the intersection of SR 3122 (Louis
Stephens Drive) / Carpenter Town Lane is unsignalized. Future build-out
conditions include one site driveway connection to SR 3122 (Louis Stephens
The Town of Cary’s C-Tran Service offers area wide transit coverage as a phone
ahead “door-to-door” or demand-responsive service. Eligible riders include
persons over 55 years old or disabled persons. Though C-Tran also offers a
fixed route system, currently no routes run along any of the studied corridors.
The closest fixed route to the proposed development runs along High House
Road, but does not approach the proposed park. Because such a small
percentage of the population is covered by this service, it is anticipated that this
service will have minimal to no impact on the proposed Development. No
adjustments will be made to anticipated traffic volumes due to this service.
Currently, sidewalks exist along all of the existing roadway facilities. It is certain
that foot traffic to the park will represent a significant portion of the incoming site
trips. No adjustments were made to anticipated traffic volumes to account for
alternative modes of transportation (motorized or non-motorized).

text.b: III. Probable Impacts of the Project

page.text: Currently there are two proposed Town of Cary developments in the project
study area that will be used as background traffic for this development. Town of
(Olde Maynard Subdivision). Additional background traffic from these
developments was included for this analysis in the 2030 no-build and build
scenarios. There were no recommended roadway improvements at either study
area intersection recommended by either development. To account for area-
wide future ambient traffic growth, an annual growth rate of 3.0 percent was
applied to the existing traffic volumes.
This value was calculated using area
Currently there are two approved roadway projects planned in the project study
area. The Louis Stephens Drive Extension project consists of the paving and
extension of SR 3122 (Louis Stephens Drive) 0.65 miles from Redwood Park
Drive northwest to the Little Drive / SR 3122 (Louis Stephens Drive) intersection
in Research Triangle Park. The project is currently scheduled for completion in
the winter of 2013. The Carpenter Fire Station Road Grade Separation Project
consists of rail crossing closures at SR 3014 (Morrisville-Carpenter Road) / SR
1623 (Indian Wells Road) and SR 1624 (Carpenter Fire Station Road). SR 3014
(Morrisville-Carpenter Road) will be realigned west of SR 3122 (Louis Stephens
Drive) to form a new intersection with NC-55 as well as a new grade separated
rail crossing. This project is still in the design phase with no scheduled
construction completion date. However, it is assumed this project will be
completed prior to the future 2030 analysis year. All analyses will be conducted
using the existing lane configuration shown. It should be noted that, because of
the two proposed projects, SEPI projected an aggressive 3% growth rate (grown
exponentially) over the next 18 years. This aggressive growth accounts for the
improved access to both NC-540 and NC-55.
The traffic generation potential was determined using the number of parking
spaces proposed for the Carpenter Park Development. To provide a
conservative analysis at the site driveway and in the study area, it was assumed
that all 30 parking spaces would completely turn over during the AM and PM
peak hours of the proposed adjacent roadway facilities. The ITE Trip Generation
411 (City Park), provides a very limited study of city parks during weekday peak
hour as peak hours for park developments typically do not coincide with the peak
hour of the adjacent streets. Park peak hours typically fall on Saturday or
Sunday when traffic on the adjacent facility is significantly lower. Projecting a
complete turn-over of all parking spaces during the AM and PM peak hours of SR
3122 (Louis Stephens Drive) represents a “worst case” scenario for park traffic.
Table ES-1 summarizes the estimated traffic generation for the park
development during the AM and PM peak hours as well as during an average
week day (per the ITE Trip Generation Manual. No attempt was made to reduce
the number of trips by a transit factor or other alternate form of transportation. A
truck percentage of two percent was assumed for all site-generated traffic.

text.b: Table ES-1 – Trip Generation Summary (Vehicles / Hour)

page.text: * Assumed 100% turn-over of 30 space parking lot
Each of the study area intersections were first analyzed under existing
conditions. The intersections (existing and future) were then analyzed with and
without the addition of site traffic for the future year (2030).
For this analysis, the following four conditions were evaluated:
Condition 2: Future Year (2030) Without Site Traffic
Condition 3: Future Year (2030) With Site Traffic
Condition 4: Future Year (2030) With Site Traffic & Recommended Site Driveway
Table ES-2 shows the results of the intersection analyses for each Condition.

text.b: Table ES-2 – Level of Service and Delay (sec/veh) Results –

page.text: N/A => Intersection not analyzed / Intersection does not exist
^=> Critical intersection movement for unsignalized intersection
Table ES-3 shows the results of the queuing analyses for Condition 3.
In conclusion, the construction of a full movement site driveway is acceptable
(based on capacity and queuing analyses) for the future Carpenter Park
Development. It is projected that the future intersection will operate at
acceptable levels of service during the 2030 Condition 3 (With Site Traffic) AM
and PM peak hours. It is also projected that adequate left-turn bay storage is
available (and will be available) for the northbound left-turning movement of the
intersection of SR 3014 (Morrisville-Carpenter Road) / SR 3122 (Louis Stephens
Drive) and the southbound left-turning movement of the proposed site driveway

The Carpenter Park Development is being proposed for construction in Cary,
North Carolina. The development is slated for construction in 2014 and will
include a 16 acre park with 30 parking spaces for park patrons.
(located in Appendix A) shows the general site location of the park
development. The proposed development is located in the southeast quadrant of
the SR 3014 (Morrisville-Carpenter Road) / SR 3122 (Louis Stephens Drive)
intersection with one site driveway proposed to connect to SR 3122 (Louis
Stephens Drive). This report analyzes the effects of a full movement and / or
partial restricted site driveway on the existing roadway network for the 2012
existing year traffic conditions, the no-build condition for 2030 (Condition 2), the
full build-out condition for the year 2030 (Condition 3) and the full build-out
condition for the year 2030 with any recommended site driveway improvements
The proposed site is currently undeveloped. Figure 2 show a preliminary
proposed project site location and position of the proposed site driveway
This report analyzes and presents the traffic impacts that the Carpenter Park
Development will have on the following (existing* and future) intersections:
 Carpenter Town Lane / SR 3122 (Louis Stephens Drive)
The impacts of the proposed site at these intersections will be evaluated during
the AM and PM peak hours of an average weekday. The following analysis is
based on the 2012 existing year traffic, the 2030 traffic with the addition of
ambient growth and without the proposed development, and the 2030 total traffic
with the addition of the estimated site-generated traffic produced by the
Carpenter Park Development. The report also analyzes the potential effects of
queuing at the intersections of SR 3014 (Morrisville-Carpenter Road) / SR 3122
(Louis Stephens Drive) and Site Driveway #1 / SR 3122 (Louis Stephens Drive).
Currently there are two approved background developments to be completed
within the surrounding region prior to the construction of the Carpenter Park
To account for area-wide 2013 ambient traffic growth, an annual growth rate
percentage of 3.0 percent per year was applied to the existing volumes. This
growth rate was calculated using area 2005 – 2009 AADT values provided by the
The capacity analysis and queuing methodology is provided by the 2000
Highway Capacity Manual (HCM 2000). Using these methods, a level of service
(LOS) is determined. Level of service is the measure that rates traffic conditions
qualitatively based on the observed and collected data for the given
transportation facility. The traffic operations optimization and evaluation software
Synchro Version 7.0 was used to evaluate the existing and proposed
SR 3014 (Morrisville-Carpenter Road) is a major arterial runs that
approximately east – west through the project study area. The facility stretches
from Aviation Parkway in Morrisville, NC westward to NC 55 in Cary. In the
project study area, SR 3014 (Morrisville-Carpenter Road) varies from a three-
lane facility to a two-lane facility and has a signalized intersection with SR 3122
(Louis Stephens Drive). The facility services both commercial and residential
developments and has a 45-mph posted speed limits east of SR 3122 (Louis
Stephens Drive) and 35-mph posted speed limit west of SR 3122 (Louis
SR 3122 (Louis Stephens Drive) is a major arterial that runs approximately
north – south through the project study area. The facility stretches from SR 1617
(Carpenter-Upchurch Road) to Redwood Park Drive. In the project study area,
SR 3122 (Louis Stephens Drive) varies from a five-lane facility to a four-lane
facility (with a grass median) and forms a signalized intersection with SR 3014
(Morrisville-Carpenter Road) and an unsignalized intersection with Carpenter
Town Lane. The facility services both commercial and residential developments
and has a posted 35-mph speed limit. For future build-out conditions, the project
site driveway will connect to this facility.
Carpenter Town Lane is a collector street that runs approximately east – west
through the project study area. The facility stretches from SR 3014 (Morrisville-
Carpenter Road) to the Magnolia residential development. In the project study
area, Carpenter Town Lane is a two lane facility and forms an unsignalized
intersection with SR 3122 (Louis Stephens Drive). The facility services
residential developments and has a posted 25-mph speed limit.
In the project study area, there is one signalized and one unsignalized
intersection. The intersection of SR 3014 (Morrisville-Carpenter Road) / SR 3122
(Louis Stephens Drive) is signalized where the intersection of SR 3122 (Louis
Stephens Drive) / Carpenter Town Lane is unsignalized. Future build-out
conditions include one site driveway connection to SR 3122 (Louis Stephens
Drive). Figure 3 shows the existing lane configuration and traffic control for each
The signalized intersection of SR 3014 (Morrisville-Carpenter Road) / SR 3122
(Louis Stephens Drive) is controlled by a five-phase traffic signal. The north and
southbound approaches each consist of an exclusive left-turn lane, a through
lane, and a right-turn lane. The eastbound and westbound approaches consist of
an exclusive left-turn lane, and a shared through / right-turn lane.
shows the existing lane configuration for this intersection.
The unsignalized intersection of Carpenter Town Lane / SR 3122 (Louis
Stephens Drive) is a two-way stop-controlled intersection the Carpenter Town
Lane approaches encountering the stopped condition. The northbound and
southbound intersection approaches each consist of an exclusive left-turn lane, a
through lane, and a shared through / right-turn lane. The eastbound and
westbound intersection approaches each consist of a single shared left / through
Figure 3 shows the existing lane configuration for this
There is one site driveway proposed to connect to SR 3122 (Louis Stephens
Drive). The site driveway connection will be analyzed as a full access driveway
and will be stop-sign controlled. Figure 2 shows the location of the proposed site
Figure 4 shows the existing AM and PM peak hour traffic volumes for the study
area intersections. The counts used to determine these volumes (see Appendix
B) were conducted by SEPI Engineering & Construction for the Carpenter Town
Lane / SR 3122 (Louis Stephens Drive) intersection and the Town of Cary for the
intersection during the respective days and times listed in Table 1 below:

text.b: E. Alternate Modes of Transportation / Transit Impacts

page.text: The Town of Cary’s C-Tran Service offers area wide transit coverage as a phone
ahead “door-to-door” or demand-responsive service. Eligible riders include
persons over 55 years old or disabled persons. Though C-Tran also offers a
fixed route system, currently no routes run along any of the studied corridors.
The closest fixed route to the proposed development runs along High House
Road, but does not approach the proposed park. Because such a small
percentage of the population is covered by this service, it is anticipated that this
service will have minimal to no impact on the proposed Development. No
adjustments will be made to anticipated traffic volumes due to this service.
Currently, sidewalks exist along all of the existing roadway facilities. It is certain
that foot traffic to the park will represent a significant portion of the incoming site
trips. No adjustments were made to anticipated traffic volumes to account for
alternative modes of transportation (motorized or non-motorized).

text.b: F. Existing Signal Phasing / Timing Information

page.text: Signal phasing and timing information for the existing signalized intersection (05-
2231) is located in Appendix C. The existing signal plan and signal timing
information was obtained from the NCDOT Signals and Geometrics Section.
Information from the plan related to signal timing offsets and phasing sequences
was used for all conditions in this analysis. Minimum green times, yellow and all
red times, etc. followed the typical NCDOT and Town of Cary standards and
Currently there are two proposed Town of Cary developments in the project
study area that will be used as background traffic for this development. Town of
(Olde Maynard Subdivision). Additional background traffic from these
developments was included for this analysis in the 2030 no-build and build
scenarios. There were no recommended roadway improvements at either study
area intersection recommended by either development.
Appendix D includes the site traffic figures for each of the background
developments. To account for area-wide future ambient traffic growth, an annual
growth rate of 3.0 percent was applied to the existing traffic volumes. This value
was calculated using area 2005-2009 AADT values. Figure 5 shows the total
2030 background traffic volumes and Figure 6 shows the 2030 without site traffic
Currently there are two approved roadway projects planned in the project study
area (see Appendix E). The Louis Stephens Drive Extension project consists of
the paving and extension of SR 3122 (Louis Stephens Drive) 0.65 miles from
Redwood Park Drive northwest to the Little Drive / SR 3122 (Louis Stephens
Drive) intersection in Research Triangle Park. The project is currently scheduled
for completion in the winter of 2013.
The Carpenter Fire Station Road Grade
Separation Project consists of rail crossing closures at SR 3014 (Morrisville-
Carpenter Road) / SR 1623 (Indian Wells Road) and SR 1624 (Carpenter Fire
Station Road). SR 3014 (Morrisville-Carpenter Road) will be realigned west of
SR 3122 (Louis Stephens Drive) to form a new intersection with NC-55 as well as
a new grade separated rail crossing. This project is still in the design phase with
no scheduled construction completion date. However, it is assumed this project
will be completed prior to the future 2030 analysis year. All analyses will be
conducted using the existing lane configuration shown in Figure 3. It should be
noted that, because of the two proposed projects, SEPI projected an aggressive
3% growth rate (grown exponentially) over the next 18 years. This aggressive
growth accounts for the improved access to both NC-540 and NC-55.
The traffic generation potential was determined using the number of parking
spaces proposed for the Carpenter Park Development. To provide a
conservative analysis at the site driveway and in the study area, it was assumed
that all 30 parking spaces would completely turn over during the AM and PM
peak hours of the proposed adjacent roadway facilities. The ITE Trip Generation
411 (City Park), provides a very limited study of city parks during weekday peak
hour as peak hours for park developments typically do not coincide with the peak
hour of the adjacent streets. Park peak hours typically fall on Saturday or
Sunday when traffic on the adjacent facility is significantly lower. Projecting a
complete turn-over of all parking spaces during the AM and PM peak hours of SR
3122 (Louis Stephens Drive) represents a “worst case” scenario for park traffic.
Table 2 summarizes the estimated traffic generation for the park development
during the AM and PM peak hours as well as during an average week day (per
the ITE Trip Generation Manual – see Appendix F). No attempt was made to
reduce the number of trips by a transit factor or other alternate form of
transportation. A truck percentage of two percent was assumed for all site-
* Assumed 100% turn-over of 30 space parking lot
The directional traffic patterns, or trip distribution, of the site-generated traffic was
determined using the existing 2012 AM and PM peak hour traffic characteristics.
It was assumed, for purposes of this study, that all site traffic would enter and exit
the study area in the same manner as the existing traffic volumes. Total trips into
and out of the study area using SR 3014 (Morrisville-Carpenter Road), SR 3122
(Louis Stephens Drive), and Carpenter Town Lane form the basis of the
percentage distribution. Distribution percentages into and out of the study area
are calculated using projected traffic volumes that enter and exit the study area.
The percentages are routed, via shortest path, to and from the proposed
development. This distribution percentage is then applied to the generated trips
to predict routes and project traffic volumes for the 2030 analysis scenario.
Figure 7 shows the 2030 distributional percentages and Figure 8 shows the
2030 site trip distribution volumes. 2030 build-out traffic volumes are determined
by applying the site trip distribution volumes to the Condition 2 traffic volumes
(see Figure 6). 2030 Condition 3 build-out traffic volumes can be found in
As an alternative to the aforementioned scenario, SEPI analyzed a “worst case
scenario” at the site driveway intersection where all 30 in-coming and out-going
vehicles will perform only left-turning movements into and out of the park
The capacity of a roadway is measured by the “level of service” it provides, as
described in the Highway Capacity Manual (Transportation Research Board,
2000). Level of service (LOS) is a measure used to describe the operating
conditions of traffic on a roadway based on characteristics such as speed, traffic
volumes, geometric configuration, delays, and freedom to maneuver. Levels of
service range from “A” to “F,” with “A” describing smooth free flow conditions, and
“F” describing congested, over-saturated and forced flow conditions, where stop-
and-go waves are common. Other factors, such as a high percentage of trucks
or buses within the traffic stream can affect level of service. The roadway
setting, whether it is urban, suburban, or rural, can also affect level of service.
For signalized intersections in urban areas, LOS D is generally considered
acceptable, while in rural areas, LOS C is considered acceptable.
At unsignalized intersections, a LOS E is generally considered acceptable if only
the side street encounters delay. Nevertheless, side streets typically function at
a LOS F during peak traffic periods, because the traffic volumes often do not
warrant a traffic signal to assist side street traffic.
general description of the various level of service categories and delay ranges:

text.b: Table 3 – Level of Service Descriptions for Intersections

page.text: The following conditions were evaluated for this analysis:
Condition 3: 2030 With Site Traffic and Site Driveway Improvements
The analysis results for unsignalized intersections were found using Synchro
Version 7.0 through the use of procedures described in the HCM 2000.
Synchro was used to analyze all unsignalized intersections. Because overall
intersection levels of service are not provided for one or two-way stop controlled
unsignalized intersections, the results were evaluated on a per-movement basis.
Thus, intersection improvements may need to be considered should one or more
of the intersection movements experience a failing level of service. This
methodology differs from signalized intersections, where one or more movement
at an intersection may be deficient, but no intersection improvements would be
deemed necessary as long as the overall intersection level of service does not
In addition to the capacity analyses, SEPI performed a queuing analysis of the
proposed site driveway southbound left-turning movement and the northbound
left-turning movement of the intersection of SR 3014 (Morrisville-Carpenter Rd) /
SR 3122 (Louis Stephens Drive). A comparison of the Condition 3 AM and PM
percentile queue measurements (found in Synchro) for the site
driveway southbound left-turn bay and signalized intersection northbound left-
turn bay were made to determine whether or not future queue spill backs will
occur and, if so, will these queue spill backs conflict. The existing northbound
left-turn bay at the intersection of SR 3014 (Morrisville-Carpenter Rd) / SR 3122
(Louis Stephens Drive) includes 200-feet of vehicle storage (with taper) and can
accommodate a queue of 8 vehicles. The proposed southbound left-turn bay for
the project site driveway is projected to be 150-feet long (with 100-foot taper) and
is projected to accommodate a 6 vehicle queue. Site driveway queue lengths
were examined using both a typical trip distribution pattern as well as a
concentrated, left-turn only, trip distribution pattern described above.
Appendix G contains the Synchro outputs for this analysis. Table 4 below
shows the results of the intersection analyses for Conditions 1 – 4. A description
of each Condition follows the table.

existing traffic volumes (see Figure 4), and existing signal timing values.

Each analysis was conducted using the existing geometric configuration, 2030
Condition 2 traffic volumes (see Figure 6), and optimized signal timing values.

page.text: Table 4 above reveals that all movements at the unsignalized intersections are
projected to operate at a LOS C or better during both peak hours of Condition 3.
The signalized intersection of SR 3014 (Morrisville-Carpenter Rd) is projected to
operate at a LOS D during the AM peak hour and a LOS E during the 2030
Each analysis was conducted using the existing
geometric configuration (with the construction of a full movement site driveway),
2030 Condition 3 traffic volumes (see Figure 9), and optimized signal timing
Appendix F contains the Synchro outputs for the queuing analyses. Table 5
below shows the results of the queuing analyses for Condition 3.
The Carpenter Park Development has one proposed site driveway connection to
SR 3122 (Louis Stephens Drive). Capacity and queuing analyses were
performed at this intersection to determine whether a full movement driveway is
acceptable at this location or if left-turning movements to and / or from the
proposed development should be restricted. The intersection was analyzed
assuming both a typical trip distribution pattern and a more concentrated, left-turn
The capacity analysis of the site driveway during the 2030 With Site Traffic
Condition (Condition 3) reveals that all movements of the site driveway
intersection are projected to operate at acceptable levels of service during both
2030 Condition 3 peak hours assuming a typical trip distribution pattern and a
more concentrated, left-turn only, trip distribution pattern. The queuing analyses
revealed that queues are not projected to spill back beyond the existing or
projected left-turn bays for either the northbound left-turning movement at the
intersection of SR 3014 (Morrisville-Carpenter Road) / SR 3122 (Louis Stephens
Drive) or the southbound left-turning movement at the proposed site driveway
percentile left-turn queue lengths do not exceed the
existing or projected storage bays during either 2030 Condition 3 peak hour.
The existing signalized intersection at SR 3014 (Morrisville-Carpenter Road) / SR
3122 (Louis Stephens Drive) currently operates at a LOS C or better during the
2012 AM and PM peak hours. For both Condition 2 and Condition 3, the addition
of background traffic and site traffic (respectively), the intersection is projected to
operate acceptably (LOS D or better) during the 2030 AM peak hour and a LOS
E during the PM peak hour. Table 4 shows the existing and projected LOS and
*It should be noted that the purpose of this analysis was not to make off-site
intersection recommendations. Though this intersection is projected to operate
at a LOS E during the 2030 Condition 2 PM peak hour and Condition 3 PM peak
hour, no capacity mitigation recommendations or analyses were provided as they
are considered outside the scope of this study.

text.b: Carpenter Town Lane / SR 3122 (Louis Stephens Drive)

page.text: All analyzed movements of the existing unsignalized intersection at Carpenter
Town Lane / SR 3122 (Louis Stephens Drive) currently operate at a LOS B or
better during the AM and PM peak hours. For Condition 2, the addition of
background traffic, all analyzed movements are projected to operate a LOS C or
better during both peak hours. For Condition 3, the addition site traffic, all
analyzed movements are projected to operate at a LOS C or better during both
peak hours. Table 4 shows the existing and projected LOS and delay values for
In conclusion, the construction of a full movement site driveway is acceptable
(based on capacity and queuing analyses) for the future Carpenter Park
Development. It is projected that the future intersection will operate at
acceptable levels of service during the 2030 Condition 3 (With Site Traffic) AM
and PM peak hours. It is also projected that adequate left-turn bay storage is
available (and will be available) for the northbound left-turning movement of the
intersection of SR 3014 (Morrisville-Carpenter Road) / SR 3122 (Louis Stephens
Drive) and the southbound left-turning movement of the proposed site driveway
